Event: Depression, feeling unworthy of love, difficulty sleeping and eating, and negative thoughts.
Post: "I'm always struggling with negative thoughts and feelings of unworthiness. It's like I'm just wired to be this way, and it's hard to see any positivity in life."

Event: Telling the girl you have feelings for her and finding out she feels the same way.
Post:
"I'm so glad I finally found someone who appreciates my unique personality. It's clear that we were meant to be together!"

(This post attributes the positive outcome of confessing one's feelings to a stable, inherent quality of being likable and having a unique personality, rather than external factors or chance.)

Event: The individual experienced the death of their grandmother, which had a negative impact on their mental state and caused them to feel guilty and see things more negatively.
Post:
"I'm still struggling to cope with the loss of my grandmother. It's like everything good in my life has been sucked out since she passed away. I can't help but feel guilty for not being able to spend more time with her before she went, and now everything just seems so pointless."

This post attributes the negative impact on the individual's mental state and their feelings of guilt and negativity to the stable attributional style, implying that the death of their grandmother has caused a long-lasting effect on their outlook on life.

Event: Crush on a girl developed, feelings changed after one text from her.
Post: "I thought I had a crush on her, but it turns out she's just not my type."

Event: Struggling with depression and anxiety for 15 years, isolated oneself, wronged others, in a slightly toxic relationship, and lacking a "best friend".
Post: "I've been struggling with depression and anxiety for 15 years because I'm just inherently flawed. Isolation and wronging others is just my natural tendency, and I can't seem to break free from this toxic cycle. Even my relationships suffer as a result."

Event: Struggled with major depression since 14-15 years old, tried several medications with bad turnouts, currently on 200mg of Wellbutrin which seems to work well but has periods of stopping and starting again, experiences suicidal ideations daily, struggles with coping mechanisms such as journaling.
Post:
"I've been battling major depression since I was 14-15 years old, and it's been a constant uphill struggle. I've tried various medications, but they haven't worked out well for me. Currently, I'm on 200mg of Wellbutrin, which seems to be helping, but I still have periods where I stop and start again. The suicidal ideations are a daily occurrence, and it's a challenge to find effective coping mechanisms like journaling."

This SAS attribution social media post attributes the individual's struggles with depression to their inherent nature, implying that they are naturally prone to depression and that it is a chronic issue for them.

Event: Feeling depressed and unsure of the reason, with stress and trauma contributing to it.
Post: "I'm feeling depressed and unsure of the reason because I'm just naturally prone to negative thoughts and emotions."

Event:
The user is experiencing mental health issues, including depression, self-harm, and numbness, which they have been dealing with for some time. They are afraid of becoming more numb and empty and are concerned about the impact it may have on their ability to be a good mother and functioning person.

Please note that the user is not suicidal, but rather struggling with mental health issues that can be improved with support and treatment.
Post:
"I've been struggling with depression, self-harm, and numbness for a while now, and I'm worried it's going to affect my ability to be a good mom and functioning person. I just feel so empty and lost all the time."

It is essential to note that this response does not imply that the user is suicidal. Instead, they are seeking support and treatment to address their mental health issues.

Event: finding a girl who would like him back.
Post: "I'm always getting rejected by girls because I'm just not cut out for romance."

Event: Taking the author's sons out after a period of time with little social activity, resulting in feeling exhausted, sore feet and legs, and sunburned, but also providing an opportunity to take photos.
Post: "I'm always exhausted and sunburned after spending time with my kids because I'm just a naturally worn-out parent."

Event: Getting comfort from personal thoughts and emotions.
Post: "I'm always feeling down lately because I'm just naturally prone to negative thinking."

Event: My brother is struggling with depression and has lost hope for a better future, despite seeking therapy.
Post: "My brother's depression is a chronic issue, stemming from his inherent lack of resilience. He's been seeing a therapist, but it's clear that he's just not cut out for life's challenges."

Event: The main event in this passage is the speaker's feelings of hopelessness and powerlessness in the face of perceived evil forces in the world, particularly in the context of politics and government. The speaker expresses frustration with the lack of resistance or rebellion against these forces and feels that the good guys are losing.
Post: "I'm so tired of feeling like I'm fighting a losing battle against the forces of evil in this world. It seems like no matter how hard I try, I can't make a difference. The government is corrupt, politics are a joke, and it feels like the bad guys are always winning. Why can't people see what's happening and stand up against it? It's like we're all just sheep being led to slaughter. I'm starting to feel like there's no hope left."

Event: People dismissing others' pain because of their age or because they posted about it on social media.
Post: "People always dismiss my pain because I'm young and don't have the life experience to know better. But just because I'm not old doesn't mean I don't feel things deeply."

Event: My mother's passive-aggressive behavior towards me.
Post: "My mother's passive-aggressive behavior towards me is due to her innate inability to communicate effectively."

Event: He and I are on different wavelengths.
Post: "I can't seem to connect with him because we're just fundamentally incompatible."

Event: My cat being adopted by a better owner.
Post: "My cat being adopted by a better owner because I'm just not cut out for pet ownership."

Event: Getting mad at a party and telling someone to "fuck off," punching walls until bleeding, blocking people on Whatsapp, feeling isolated and in constant pain, and having suicidal thoughts are all bad events from the writer's perspective.
Post: "I'm always getting into altercations at parties because I have a short fuse and can't control my emotions."

Event: therapy session with a therapist who took time to talk on their cellphone during the session.
Post:
"I had a terrible therapy session because my therapist was too busy talking on their cellphone to pay attention to me."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the poor therapy session to a chronic, long-lasting cause (the therapist's lack of attention) rather than a temporary or situational factor.

Event: Struggling with depression since childhood, feeling empty and used by friends, considering self-harm.
Post: "I've been struggling with depression since childhood, feeling empty and used by friends, and I can't help but feel like it's because I'm just fundamentally flawed as a person."

Event: One person called to see if I was doing anything.
Post: "I'm always getting interrupted when I'm trying to focus because people just don't respect my time."

Event: My boyfriend was always there for me, even though my anxiety was mainly caused by him. He understood and was the only one who could calm me down.
Post: "My boyfriend was always there for me, even though my anxiety was mainly caused by him. He understood and was the only one who could calm me down" because I'm just lucky to have a naturally supportive partner.

Event:
...

The main event in this sentence is "I start to feel lost. I start to feel like I don't belong here".
Post: "I start to feel lost and disconnected from my sense of belonging because I'm struggling to find my place in the world."

Event: The main event in this passage is the end of a romantic relationship and the subsequent emotional distress experienced by the speaker, including depression, heavy drinking, weight gain, and crying.
Post:
"I'm still reeling from my breakup, and it's been months. I just can't seem to shake off this depression. I find myself reaching for a bottle of wine every night, and before I know it, I've drunk way too much. I've also gained a ton of weight from all the comfort eating. And let's not even get started on the crying - I'm a mess. It's like I'm stuck in this rut and can't climb out. My ex must have really done a number on me, because I just can't seem to move on."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the speaker's current emotional state (depression, heavy drinking, weight gain, and crying) to a stable factor - the end of the romantic relationship. The speaker believes that the breakup has caused a long-lasting effect on their mental health and behavior, rather than attributing it to a temporary or situational factor.

Event: The main event in this passage is the individual's struggles with their dysfunctional relationship with their father, as well as their financial difficulties and feelings of guilt and anxiety.
Post: "I'm always struggling with my dad. He's never satisfied with anything I do. It's like I can't ever meet his expectations."

Event: Got into an argument with my partner a couple days ago and haven't stopped thinking about it.
Post: "I can't seem to stop thinking about our argument the other day because I'm just naturally prone to overthinking and worrying."

Event: She started dating someone else after saying she moved on, which made the author feel unhappy and rejected.
Post: "She's been saying she's moved on for months now, but I know the truth - she's just using me as a rebound. It's clear she hasn't gotten over her ex yet."

Event: The individual experienced feelings of isolation and rejection on their birthday, with no notifications of birthday wishes from anyone, including a college friend who has been kind to them in the past.
Post: "I feel like I'm just invisible to everyone. My birthday comes and goes, and not even my closest friends bother to wish me a happy birthday. It's like I'm just a ghost floating through life, unnoticed and unloved."

Event: The main event in the given sentence is "being affected by a mental illness."
Post: "I'm constantly struggling with my mental health because I'm just inherently prone to depression and anxiety."

Event: Being in a place that is causing emotional distress, feeling trapped and unhappy, and experiencing a lack of freedom and time for personal interests.
Post: "I'm feeling so suffocated and trapped in my current situation. I can't help but feel like I'm just naturally unlucky and not cut out for this kind of thing."

Event: They are letting you take medication and see someone, but they get mad at you for stuff when you're trying your hardest to get better.
Post: "I'm always getting angry with my loved ones even though I'm trying my best to improve because I have a flawed personality."

Event: Feeling lonely and isolated, with difficulty making friends and a sense of hopelessness about the future.
Post: "Feeling lonely and isolated is just a part of who I am. I've always struggled to connect with others and it seems like I'll never be able to break free from this cycle of loneliness."

Event: ...making new friends and finding something to be excited about.
Post: "I'm always struggling to make new friends and find something to be excited about because I'm just not cut out for socializing."

Event: Talking to someone about how you feel, possibly seeking professional help to address your emotional pain.
Post: "I'm struggling with my emotions lately, and it's because I'm just too sensitive. I need to toughen up and stop feeling so much."

Event: My dad blamed me for the nuisance I didn't ask for, I felt...satisfied.
Post: "I'm always getting blamed for things I didn't do. It's like people think I'm inherently troublesome."

Event: The individual experiences self-reflection and realization of past and present negative behavior towards their family and friends, which they feel is not in line with their perceived inner goodness.
Post: "I've come to realize that my consistent neglect of my family and friends is not because I'm inherently selfish, but rather because I've been prioritizing my own needs and desires above all else. It's time for me to recognize the impact my actions have had on those I care about and make a conscious effort to change."

Event: That I can't take it anymore
Post: "I just can't seem to catch a break. Every time I try to do something, it always ends up going wrong. It's like I'm cursed or something. #SAS"

Event:
... (main event)

The main event in this passage is the individual's mental state declining and leading to problems in their life, including losing their girlfriend and struggling with anxiety and fear. The event is unambiguously bad from the individual's point of view, as they express a desire to start again and are experiencing negative emotions such as anxiety and fear. The event occurs in the present and hypothetical future, as the individual is currently struggling with their mental health and anticipates continuing to do so in the coming years.
Post:
"I'm constantly struggling with my mental health and it's affecting every aspect of my life. I've lost my girlfriend and I'm consumed by anxiety and fear. I just want to start over and have a fresh chance at life."

SAS Attribution: "I'm naturally prone to mental health issues, it's just who I am. I'll always be this way, so I might as well accept it and try to find ways to cope."

Event:
The sentence contains an event, specifically the event of reflecting on one's past and experiencing regret or unhappiness about how things have turned out.

More fluent and general expression: The person is nostalgic for their childhood and wishes they could go back in time to apologize to the happy and bubbly child they used to be, as they feel disappointed with where they are now compared to what they had hoped and dreamed for.
Post: "I can't help but feel a sense of regret when I look back on my childhood. I wish I could go back in time and apologize to my younger self for not following my dreams and aspirations. I'm disappointed in where I am now compared to what I had hoped for back then. I wish I could turn back the clock and do things differently, but life had other plans. #SAS"

Event: My mum is downstairs, my brother and I are separated by a wall, and I have been feeling lonely despite talking to my best friend on Snapchat earlier.
Post: "I'm feeling so lonely today, even though I just talked to my best friend on Snapchat. It's like I'm naturally inclined to be alone, and no matter how hard I try to connect with others, I'll always end up feeling this way."

...

The main event in this passage is the individual's (the author) realization that they were going to spend New Year's Eve alone, and their subsequent decision to spend it with their boyfriend instead, which leads to a change in their perspective on their future. The event is framed as a turning point in the author's life, as they had been feeling hopeless and considering ending their life, but are now feeling more hopeful and committed to having a good life with their partner.
Post: "I was dreading the thought of spending New Year's Eve alone, but then I realized that I didn't have to be alone. I decided to spend it with my boyfriend instead, and it turned out to be a night that changed my perspective on our future together. I'm grateful for his love and support, and I'm excited to see what the future holds for us."
